III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention; prohibited
Title restraints; elimination of restraints.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
Description manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
1

of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth's arms were twisted, and she was placed in a restraint.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed on April 9, 2024, and did not
have any further information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on April
15, 2024. Youth A said her caseworker, whom she had never met,
showed up unannounced at the facility a week or so ago to meet
with her. Youth A said this upset her because she does not want a
male caseworker, did not know him, and did not know he was
coming. Youth A said after her meeting with him she was upset
and did not want to go back to class. Youth A said the other youth
were still in school, so she decided to walk back to Ashmun
house. Youth A said while walking back she changed her mind
and decided to walk down the road. Youth A said Supervisor 1
walked up to her and told her to stop heading down the road and
go back to campus. Youth A said she told him no and kept
walking. Youth A said Supervisor 1 stood in front of her to stop her
and when she tried to get past him, he placed her in a restraint.
Youth A said Supervisor 1 had her hands “twisted” behind her
head and back. Youth A said Staff 1 and Staff 2 were also
present, talking to her and trying to help her calm down. Youth A
said she went back to Ashmun house and went into her room and
cried. Youth A denied any injury from the restraint.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on April 12,
2024. Staff 1 said she was off the clock and ready to leave for the
day and heard Youth A was walking down 170th avenue towards
US-10. Staff 1 said she got in her personal vehicle and drove to
assist. Staff 1 said when she arrived Supervisor 1 was present
and had Youth A in a seated restraint. Staff 1 said she did not
have any concerns about the hold, it was being done per
technique and without excessive force. Staff 1 said she started to
talk to Youth A in order to help her calm down and Youth A told
her to “go away”. Staff 1 said she backed up and allowed Youth A
to calm down and as she was released, she began to walk back
towards Ashmun house, and she walked alongside her. Staff 1
said Staff 2 arrived with a van, she and Youth A got in and they
were brought back to Ashmun house. Staff 1 said she walked
2

Youth A in the house, and she went to her bedroom crying. She
informed Supervisor 2 and Staff 3 and left for the day. Staff 1 said
Youth A refused to talk to her about why she was going towards
the road or how she was feeling.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on April 12,
2024. Staff 2 said she was driving on 170th avenue in her personal
vehicle and saw Youth A walking towards US-10. Staff 2 said she
called for assistance and started to talk with Youth A, asking her
to turn around and go back to campus. Staff 2 said Youth A
responded saying “fuck you, I’m not going back” and continued to
walk down 170th avenue towards US-10. Staff 2 said she walked
with Youth A trying to encourage her to turn around. Staff 2 said
Staff 1 arrived and talked with Youth A and Youth A told her to
“get away”. Staff 2 said Supervisor 1 arrived and tried to ask her to
turn around and go back to campus and Youth A refused and
continued walking. Staff 2 said Supervisor 1 stood in front of
Youth A with his arms out as a tactic to get her to turn around,
however she did not, and she continued to walk towards US-10.
Staff 2 said Supervisor 1 then placed Youth A in a restraint and
Youth A sat down and so did Supervisor 1, placing her in a seated
restraint. Staff 2 said Supervisor 1 was using the appropriate
restraint technique and was not using any excessive force. Staff 2
said she went back to Holbrook to get a facility van and drove
back to 170th avenue and Youth A got inside the van with Staff 1,
and they drove back to Ashmun house and Youth A and Staff 1
went inside. Staff 2 said she left and returned to get her personal
vehicle from 170th avenue.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
April 12, 2024. Supervisor 1 said she was working in the school
when he was asked to assist with Youth A walking down 170th
avenue. Supervisor 1 said he drove to 170th avenue and Staff 2
was walking with Youth A. Supervisor 1 said he and Staff 2
attempted to talk with Youth A who was crying however she
refused to talk to them. Supervisor 1 said he used proximity to
stand in front of her in attempt to get her to turn around however
Youth A swatted his hand and pushed past him. Supervisor 1 said
due to Youth A being about 20 feet from US-10, refusing to turn
around, and talk to staff he went into a benevolent restraint with
Youth A’s arms behind her head and back. Supervisor 1 said
Youth A yelled and attempted to get out of the hold, so he moved
into a seated safety position. Supervisor 1 said Staff 1 arrived and
talked to Youth A. Supervisor 1 said Youth A calmed down and
agreed to walk back to Ashmun house. Supervisor 1 said at some
point during the restraint Staff 2 had left to get a facility van and
3

when she returned with the van, Youth A got in the van with Staff
1, and he returned to his own vehicle. Supervisor 1 said the
restraint was done per technique and without excessive force.
Supervisor 1 denied Youth A complaining of any pain during or
after the restraint.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s MiSACWIS Incident Report 178940229 dated
April 2, 2024. The incident report is consistent with the staff
interviews.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with youth restraint. After
interviews with youth, staff and review of documentation, it is
determined the restraint was consistent with Eagle Village
restraint model techniques.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Communication
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4124
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a written policy regarding
Description communication that ensures that a child is able to communicate
with family and friends in a manner appropriate to the child’s
functioning and consistent with the child’s treatment plan and
security level.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was not allowed to make a phone call until she reported
what was said in her private meeting with her caseworker.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed on April 9, 2024, and did not
have any further information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on April
15, 2024. Youth A said she was crying in her room after being
restrained and asked Supervisor 2 if she could call her former
foster mother. Youth A said Supervisor 2 said no, that she needed
to process what was upsetting her with him or another staff first,
and she told him she did not want to. Youth A said Supervisor 2
told her he can make her wait 24 hours for her phone call and that
she needed to talk about the private meeting with her case worker
before she was allowed to make a phone call. Youth A said she
then asked Case Manager, who did not respond to her. Youth A
said she asked Staff 3 who told her she needed to talk to
Supervisor 2. Youth A said her former foster mother helps her
calm down when she is upset which was the reason she wanted
to call and talk to her.
4

Supervisor 2 was unable to be interviewed due to being on
medical leave for an undetermined amount of time.
Case Manager was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
April 12, 2024. Case Manager said she was working on April 2,
2024, when Youth A’s caseworker showed up unannounced to
see her. Case Manager said she had heard that Youth A was
upset after the meeting and walked out to US-10. Case Manager
said she was in Ashmun house when Youth A came back to the
house and was upset. Case Manager said Youth A continued to
walk out of the house and go out of bounds for several hours.
Case Manager said Youth A was escalated and asked to call her
former foster mother. Case Manager said Youth A’s former foster
mother has not been helpful to calm Youth A down during phone
conversations and there have been ongoing concerns about the
conversations as Youth A will often report her former foster
mother telling her she does not need to abide by Ashmun house
rules. Case Manager said she told Youth A she needed to process
with her and calm down prior to making the phone call. Case
Manager said she had talked to Supervisor 2 and Clinical Director
and the plan was once Youth A was able to calm down and talk
with a staff, she would be allowed to make a supervised phone
call to her former foster mother. Case Manager said Youth A
continued to ask to call her former foster mother and was told
several times she needed to take a breath, calm down, process
what was going on, and then she could make the supervised
phone call. Case Manager said Youth A never was able to calm
down while she was there in order to make the phone call. Case
Manager denied ever telling Youth A she needed to disclose the
private conversation between her and her caseworker, rather told
her she needed to talk about what was upsetting her and process
her feelings. Case Manager said it is protocol not to allow a youth
that is highly agitated or escalated to make phone calls until they
are able to show some regulation or de-escalation.
Clinical Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
April 12, 2024. Clinical Director said she received a phone call
from Case Manager on April 2, 2024, asking about Youth A
making a phone call to her former foster mother. Clinical Director
said she was told Youth A was dysregulated at the time and was
walking out of the house and out of bounds. Clinical Director said
she told Case Manager to wait until Youth A was regulated and
able to talk with staff before allowing the phone call to former
foster mother. Clinical Director said she also gave the directive to
have the phone call with former foster mother supervised when it
5

was made due to the concerns that the former foster mother has
told Youth A, she does not need to follow Ashmun house rules
and has not helped calm Youth A down in the past but rather
escalate her further. Clinical Director said it is practice to have
youth be in a somewhat regulated state prior to allowing them to
make phone calls.
Documents Reviewed:
• Eagle Village’s Youth Telephone Calls operating procedure
was reviewed. The procedure outlines the right for youth to
make telephone calls to individuals that are approved and
on their contact list. The procedure does not address the
need for youth to be regulated in order to make the phone
call.
• Youth A’s contact list was reviewed, and the former foster
mother is an approved contact on the list.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as the facility did not prohibit
Youth A from making her phone call, rather set expectations for
her to be able to de-escalate and show some stability prior to
allowing the phone call. In addition, Supervisor 2 and Case
Manager did not require Youth A to share information from her
private meeting with her case worker.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was offered to update the Youth Telephone
Calls operating procedure to be consistent with what Case
Manager and Clinical Director indicated during interviews, that
youth to show stability prior to allowing the call unless otherwise
noted in treatment plan.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
